title: 115_s1172
content: The Act may be cited as the "Global Respect Act of 2017". Congress finds that the dignity, freedom, and equality of all human beings are fundamental to a thriving global community. The rights to life, liberty, security of the person, privacy, and freedom of expression are essential. There is a concerning trend of violence against LGBT individuals worldwide, with many countries criminalizing same-sex relations. Countries like Nigeria, Russia, Uganda, and Kyrgyzstan have passed legislation targeting LGBT individuals. Thousands of individuals are affected by this discrimination annually. Every year, thousands of individuals worldwide face harassment, attack, arrest, and murder based on their sexual orientation or gender identity. Perpetrators often act with impunity, fueled by homophobic and transphobic statements from government officials. Authorities in various sectors have been complicit in abuses against LGBT individuals, including arbitrary arrest, torture, and sexual abuse. Celebrations of LGBT individuals and communities are often targeted with violence. Laws criminalizing same-sex relations hinder access to HIV/AIDS treatment for LGBT individuals. Some countries are improving the protection of LGBT rights. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines "appropriate congressional committees" as specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives, and "foreign person" as per a specific section in the Code of Federal Regulations. SEC. 4. IDENTIFICATION OF FOREIGN PERSONS RESPONSIBLE FOR GROSS VIOLATIONS OF HUMAN RIGHTS. The President must submit a list of foreign persons responsible for human rights violations every 180 days. This includes torture, prolonged detention without trial, and inciting violence based on sexual orientation or gender identity. The President must update a list of foreign persons involved in human rights violations every 180 days. The list must be submitted in unclassified form, with the option to include names in a classified annex under certain conditions. The Secretary of State will provide guidance on how to submit names of potential individuals for inclusion on the list. The President must update a list of foreign persons involved in human rights violations every 180 days. Names can be included in a classified annex if deemed vital for national security, consistent with congressional intent, and justified despite publicly available information. The President must consider certain information when preparing the list. The President must consider information from congressional committees, other countries, and organizations monitoring human rights violations when updating the list of foreign persons involved in such violations. The unclassified portion of the list must be made public. A foreign person can be removed from the list if credible information supports it. The criteria for removing a foreign person from the list include credible information that they did not engage in the activity, appropriate prosecution for their actions, or a significant change in behavior with a commitment to not engage in such activities. Requests from congressional committee members must be addressed within 120 days. The President must submit a response regarding the status of a foreign person to the chairperson or ranking member if they meet the criteria for being added to the list. The response can be classified if deemed necessary for national security. If the President removes a foreign person from the list, they must provide information to congressional committees that contributed to the decision. The President may submit classified information if necessary for national security interests to remove a foreign person from the list. The list required by the President shall be published without regard to confidentiality requirements for visa records. SEC. 5. INADMISSIBILITY OF CERTAIN INDIVIDUALS. Individuals on the list required by section 4(a) are ineligible for US visas and admission. The Secretary of State will revoke visas and the Secretary of Homeland Security will remove ineligible individuals from the US. Waivers for national security interests may be granted by the Secretaries in consultation with the President. The Secretaries may grant waivers for individuals on the list if necessary for US compliance with international agreements or in the national security interests of the United States. Congressional committees must be notified and provided with a justification before granting the waiver. The Secretaries can grant waivers for individuals on the list if needed for US compliance with international agreements or national security interests. Notice and justification must be provided to Congressional committees before granting the waiver. Regulatory regulations must be prescribed within 180 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 6. REPORT TO CONGRESS. The President, through the Secretary of State, must submit an annual report to Congress on the actions taken to implement the Act, including adding or removing foreign persons from the list, analyzing changes year-over-year, and coordinating with other countries. The Act requires the President to submit an annual report to Congress on implementing the Act, including adding or removing foreign persons from the list and coordinating with other countries. It also encourages other countries to impose similar sanctions. SEC. 7. DISCRIMINATION RELATED TO SEXUAL ORIENTATION OR GENDER IDENTITY. The Assistant Secretary of State for Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor designates officers to track violence and restrictions on fundamental freedoms based on sexual orientation or gender identity. Amendments are made to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 for annual country reports on human rights practices. Amendments are made to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to include information on violence or discrimination based on sexual orientation or gender identity in annual country reports on human rights practices.
